name: 1-benzyloxy-3-iodobenzene
Reason: 1-benzyloxy-3-iodobenzene has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The introduction of the iodine atom increases the melting point due to the formation of iodine-containing compounds, which have a higher melting point than hydrogen-bonded compounds. The benzyloxy group introduces a rigid structure, which raises the melting point due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. The iodine atom also participates in hydrogen bonding, which lowers the melting point. The net effect is a complex interplay between these functional groups. The iodine atom introduces a significant increase due to the formation of iodine-containing compounds, estimated at around +20 °C. The benzyloxy group introduces a rigid structure, estimated at around +10 °C. The iodine atom also participates in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around -5 °C. The net effect is a complex interplay between these functional groups.
